prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her situation with five kids by different fathers is why she's having trouble finding a partner. 

First, I need to understand the context. The friend has been making repeated, insulting comments about the author's appearance, job, and dating life. The author tried to brush off the insults for two years but finally responded by pointing out the friend's situation as a possible reason for her lack of success in dating.

The friend became angry and hung up. Now mutual friends are criticizing the author for having "skinny privilege" and being entitled, even though the author mentions they work hard and have an MBA. The author feels wronged because they believe they're not privileged and were just defending themselves.

So, the main issue is whether the author's response was justified. The friend's behavior was clearly hurtful and insulting, but the author's response was direct and potentially sensitive. Even if the statement is true, bringing up someone's personal situation (like having multiple kids with different fathers) can be very hurtful and may not be the right approach, even if the friend was being mean.

The key here is whether the author crossed a line by addressing the root cause of the friend's situation. While the friend's comments were inappropriate, the author's response might have been seen as attacking the friend's personal life, which could be considered a low blow. Friends might feel that the author was being judgmental, especially if it's a sensitive topic. Even if the friend was in the wrong for the insults, the author's response could have been hurtful in return, escalating the conflict.

Also, considering the mutual friends' reactions, they might feel the author was being unkind despite the provocation. There might be a better way to handle it, like setting boundaries without attacking the friend's personal choices. So, even if the author had a reason to be upset, the way they responded could be seen as wrong because it targeted the friend's personal issues rather than just standing up for themselves without reciprocating the negativity.

Therefore, the answer might lean towards A (author is in the wrong) because they responded with a potentially hurtful statement about the friend's personal life, even if the friend had been insulting them. However, there's nuance because the friend was being a jerk first. But in terms of the situation as presented, the author's response is likely seen as crossing a line.
